reviews.review_msg: You'll probably end up self-learning all the materials; attending his lectures won't help. His notes don't make much sense when you read it on your own, and since his lectures aren't recorded, then you're left puzzled when reading them. Assignments are vague, even the TAs couldn't do some questions; they would provide solutions copied from online.

He did 2 hour lectures and 1 hour problem sessions. Lectures were hard to follow as they were very dense and mathematical. I often found myself not fully understanding one point then being lost for the rest of the lecture. Definitely a class where you rely heavily on the textbook. Posts lecture slides but no recordings or problem solutions.

Fairly low workload, but very challenging with Shermer. He doesn't teach anything so your best bet is to read all the textbook sections he says the exams will be on and do as many textbook problems as you can. Everyone does pretty poorly objectively, but the course is graded on a curve so you pretty much just have to outperform your peers.

Brutal course with horrible prof, impossible to tell what exam questions will be like because Shermer provides no practice exams. Exams are are extremely difficult and just understanding algorithms is not enough. Workload is fair with only 4 assignments, but content is very challenging. Course is 100% self-study as lectures are useless.

He tried to make lectures online, but he speaks a normal talking speed if you speed up the video to x2. That is if you watch the lectures at all. They do NOT explain any of the material, they are an introduction to SOME important subjects, and don't clarify anything. His office hours are him saying re-read the chapters.
We're a month into the semester and so far he has been quite bad at conveying the material in my opinion and also the way he speaks puts you to sleep. His notes are also quite bad.
Never in my life have I ever been happy to get a C+ before.

Came into this class as a proud fourth year CS major with a 3.81 GPA. Averaged 38% on his four quizzes (60% of the grade!) and managed an incredible 44% on his final exam (the other 40% of the grade!). Apparently I should feel good?

Do. Not. Take. ANYTHING. With. Him!!!!! HE. DOES. NOT. CARE. ABOUT. YOU.
Showed up to the final hoping for some leniency from the prof. Nope. Average 35%. This is how the entire semester went. Nearly everyone failing.
Average of the final exam was around 35%. The entire class average was around the same mark with the 4 quizzes. This is absurd.
Final average was 35%.
Out of all the classes I have ever taken, this one is thee most difficult one. I spoke to others who said it's a difficult class but average was 60-70%. Our average was 30%.

I want students to know that if you are going to take this class with him as the prof, you must be ready to accept a failing average. No matter how many hours you think you put in, you will not pass all quizzes. Maybe if you are lucky you pass 1. Otherwise, just take it with another prof.
Very bad prof. Just like what everyone else said.

He doesn't know how to test his students. I honestly did not know what I wrote down on any quiz and final question. I could have wrote an essay and still got 0/10 on the question. If you don't have the exact wording, you aren't getting part marks.

What a roller coaster of a semester only because of this class. The workload is fairly low but the difficulty is on another level. You have 50 minutes per quiz to hope to get 2-3 out of the 5 questions done as they are very time consuming and need quite a lot of thinking. The final exam was like 2 quizzes combined and people had blank pages.
The worst.

A very very difficult class that is very important. We didn't get tested on many actual data structures and algorithms but more so of proofs. At some points I had no idea what I should write due to how difficult he structured the questions and how limited time we had.
This professor is a huge red flag. No wonder the average of his last semester was a C-. We are averaging a fail after the final and this class just puts you into depression.
The entire class average was a fail. We were averaging below 40%. The final exam I expect average 30%. So what does he do? Fail everyone? Make the average a C-? This class is impossible.
Quiz 4 which is the last quiz… average is still a fail. So all quizzes had an average of failing, and the final exam was 10x harder.

The worst class I ever took at SFU. Avoid at all costs. The lectures didn't match the homework or the quizzes. I ended up dropping the course with a WD on my transcript, and I am glad I did. I saw my friends in the class suffer immensely.
The end of this course, still an absolutely avoid. This prof doesn't know what students should learn / get tested on. Astonished by how bad everyone did. The final exam is going to be the same.
Final exam day, already feeling the failing average.

I knew I should have dropped this course when I had the chance. Now I'm staring at a 32% average in the class going into a 3 hour final with no knowledge on what to expect. Truly one of a kind class that makes you think on how dumb you are.
Final exam tomorrow, no prep given. Told us to go over previous quizzes and homework. Like we didn't do that for the quizzes and the average came out to be 20%. This guy has lost it.

Doesn't even show up on quiz days and lets the TA's handle it. He really did not care about this class nor what he quizzes us on. Take this class with a different prof and save the misery before it is too late.

Quiz 4 was fair. But it took him 3 quizzes to finally give a fair quiz. I highly doubt the average is more than 45% though. So we will see. Final exam next week, no cheat sheet, this is a disaster class still.

Basically what every other 1/5 review has said, I agree. Enough said, don't try to be smart and think you can pass his quizzes. He doesn't even show up to the quizzes either, his TA's do. Absolute garbage and waste of money. Already re enrolled in the other section for next semester.

Quiz 4, the last quiz is coming up tomorrow. I assume more reviews will be posted on how bad this class has been. Average around 35% of the class right now heading into this and final exam week. Most will fail, hopefully they can ride the curve to a pass? Who knows, this prof has absolutely lost the entire class.

Avoid. Three quizzes so far (45% of total mark) with failing averages (and lower medians). Highest grade is ~70-80% out of ~120 students (3-4 students). Curves to a C-, most students will have to retake the class. Feels like I'm being hazed. This course needs so much more to be taught properly.

MISERABLE MISERABLE MISERABLE!!! CLASS AVERAGES OF 30 40 THEN BELOW 30!!! SMALL SMALL MAN WHO WANTS TO SHOW OFF HIS POWER TO STUDENTS!!! QUIZZES TOO LONG AND CHALLENGING TO BE DONE IN 50 MINS WHEN THE BEST BRIGHTEST STUDENT IN THE CLASS CANT GET A 70!!!

I want other students to know to never take a class with him. You might only need this to graduate and there might not be another section option, just wait for another semester. You might think you'll pass, but you won't. Don't take this class with him, you will fail every quiz and need to stress about taking it again. Horrible prof.
I'm not even learning anymore. Just trying to survive. Part marks is what I am for and I still get 0's. Average so low I thought it couldn't get any lower.

To be truthfully honest, what is even going on in this class. Nobody can pass a quiz, the average was just 28%. This is the third time he's done this out of three quizzes. We got the last quiz next week and I doubt it isn't anything better. See y'all again next sem in this class. Different prof = 10x better class.
Wow, another failing quiz. Not sure what he gets from this but now I have to re-enrol into this course since we are all failing.
Quiz 3 average: the worst one yet. 28%. Again, so far 3 quizzes and all 3 average is a fail.
Worst professor at SFU. How this guy got a teaching job makes me question the faculty.
Failing average, like way below failing. I talking about 30%.
Amazing horrible at teaching data structures. Not sure what he expects on those quizzes.
Failing average quizzes for all quizzes so far.

I believe that almost all the 1 rating reviews are accurate. However his lectures sometimes could be useful, his quizzes are very time crunched and difficult. You are only given quizzes and a final exam in this class so the chances of failing is very high. If you can, take this class with another professor as this is just not worth the struggle.
I woke up today and remembered I'm in his class. Scary.

Quiz 1: horrible, average failed. Quiz 2: better than horrible , not decent enough average was 40%. Quiz 3: worse than horrible. Average will be a fail again. Quiz 4: ? We'll find out what the final quiz holds. Avoid avoid avoid avoid avoid avoid avoid avoid avoid avoid this class with him.
Dog water class.
Listen to all these reviews and avoid taking this class with him. Be smart, there's no point of spending money just to fail the class.
Still recovering from quiz 3. 100% failed it with most of the class.

Quiz 3 was wayyy too long. We only had 50 minutes but the quiz was designed for 1.5-2 hours. The average will again be around 30% because everyone has said the same thing. It was to difficult and time consuming. The homework can barely prepare you and the lecture slides you literally need to memorize.

He gave us the quiz, and it had a piece of hair on it. I tried to swipe it off but it didn't move, I realized he photo copied it on it. This threw me off and I couldn't remember anything I studied for. Another sneaky move by a prof who doesn't know we only have 50 minutes so 5 DP questions isn't suitable.
Quiz 3 was harder than the first and that average was 30%. Getting ready to fail with most of the class.

What Happened? His ratings used to be good, and now he is one of the worst professors, making a otherwise insightful class, an absolute nightmare where you don't learn anything. I would avoid this professor and take this class with anyone else possible.

His lecture notes are complicated for no apparent reason. He is one of those guys that try to be smart by doing more than what is needed without knowing what he really is doing. That's this class. The aim for each quiz is write something down so you can pull a few marks and ride the average of 30%.
Yep, I agree with the rest of these ratings,
Just don't.

Cmpt 307 is far more easier with any other prof. He's making it insanely difficult with very low averages. I am not even learning anything that we should be learning in this course. Instead, I'm trying to memorize random theorems that will never help me in the real work force. This is an absolute nightmare and you must avoid taking it.

His lectures are engaging. However, the quizzes and assignments are extremely unfair. The number and difficulty of questions are unreasonable for a 50-minute timeframe. He seems to expect students to attend office hours regularly, but not everyone has the time or flexibility to do that. I'll be avoiding his courses in the future.

Alright we just did quiz 2. And that was alright. 3 questions only and 80 marks. If you don't know how to do the first part then you can't do the rest. + he chose an algorithm he barely went over and made it consist of like 30+ marks.
All the reviews this year are true. He's really a 1/5. Any thumbs down you see are by him. Avoid this class.

A course like this should teach you how to use data structures / algorithms and when. Not prove every single small instance of random non important details. This isn't discreet math. But he makes it like it is.
Last year average of this class was a C-. Now only 24 people pass quiz 1. The trend continues of his disastrous teaching.
Quizzes were too hard and the homework barely connects well into the material we are taught. Dropped.

4 quizzes and a final seemed reasonable for a class like this. Until his quizzes turned out to be nearly imspossible to get full marks on. The highest mark was 70% and the average was 30%. Majority of the class failed and he thinks he's cool by saying he'll fail most of the class. He shouldn't be a prof, he can't teach. Avoid. Avoid. AVOID.

I didn't believe the other reviews. People tend to over react and say these things when they don't like the prof. Boy I was wrong. 32% average on quiz, no scale, majority of the class failed, and he still has the audacity to speak on suffering and willing to fail the class. How does sfu even select their profs. Horrible. Do not consider this dude.
This dude got 5/5 stars like years ago. Idk how one can age that fast and became the worst prof at sfu?

What a joke of a class. “Data structures and algorithms”… more like “Confusion and failures”…garbage, do not take this prof! Read the rest of the reviews!!!! He literally cannot teach what he quizzes if his life depends on it.

Imagine waking up, going to class and watching this dude “teach”. Then you go home, and open the homework and notice that 10% is taught and nothing else makes sense. Then you go into the quiz and you get only 30% and he says he won't scale or curve when 80% of the class failed. Boring, garbage, can't teach, not learning, more crying, avoid!!!!!!!

If you can wait to take this class, do so with another professor. This man just made an already hard class nearly impossible to pass. Average is 30% and he literally said he is willing to fail the class. He also spoke about suffering. He talks more about failing the class instead of teaching the class. Outdated, material doesn't connect to the quiz
Homework isn't even close to his lectures / notes. Then you have his homework only covering like 10% of the quiz. No wonder why 80% of the class failed quiz 1.
Don't trust any review that says he is above 1/5. He would be a 0/5 if that was an option. Worst prof of sfu.

Yeah, everyone agrees this dude can't teach nor does he care about the students. If 24 people passed out of 120 and he isn't willing to scale, that speaks for itself. He acts like he's so smart and knows everything but in reality he's taking advantage of the students. How is this guy even teaching?

Like everyone else is saying this semester: full of himself, can't teach, average of quiz is 30%, only 20 people passed, won't scale and willing to fail most of the class, boring material. Avoid at all costs, what a absolute joke of a prof.

What was that first quiz? 30% average and said he will not scale or curve and fail the class? His quizzes aren't even close to the lecture material and he seems very full of himself. He cannot teach and his slides are horrible.
He has said he doesn't mind failing majority of the class. This was after the average of quiz 1 was 30% and only 24 out of 120 people passed from it.

First Exam Class Average: 32%. The highest grade is 70%. The exams are in no way related to what he is teaching and to add, the homework is not related at all to what he taught in class. For the exam, there are no practice exams or practice questions. AVOID AT ALL COSTS. How he is employed at SFU is beyond me.
the antichrist. no exam average should be a 32/100.
and department approved his C- avg thing. wow

to be honest, I felt like if I was just memorizing bunch of random algorithms for this class. He is a good lecturer, but not a fan of how he dealt with the class.  he grades you by very few things. He didn't bother to scale/curve the class and left the avg to be C-. Avoid him.
The course avg was C- and not be curved. Great professor!

Lectures are read out of slides but slides are not useful for studying. Hmwk doesn't help with learning and quizzes are hard b/c there is not enough direction from lectures and hmwk to learn the fundamentals.

Overall, material is doable but the education design could be a lot better. If you test poorly, take a prof that has assignments. Curved.

Don't be misled by the other ratings. This course is hard no doubt, and Valentine teaches well but his quizzes are extremely hard and long. Not doable in 50 mins. He has 4 quizzes each 15% and a final for 40%.

Kabanets was a great prof to take 307 with. His lectures were very clarifying and he is very helpful during office hours. His handwriting is messy, but I was able to read it. I only wish his exams were a bit easier. But note that he does reuse questions from previous times he's taught this course.

CMPT 307 is extremely hard and Kabanets has tried to make our life a little bit easier. You will definitely learn a lot about the most popular type of algorithms, but you should study hard because his tests are very complicated. I'd reccomend to visit his office hours and to do all exercises from your homework.

307 is DIFFICULT. Study the material and do the homeworks when he posts them. Kabanets is a very friendly guy and he will do his best to make sure you understand the hard topics. Go to his office hours, even if its just to sit there and listen to other peoples questions. And dont be afraid to ask questions, the course content is very difficult!

Very good teacher! His lectures are great and he makes a lot of effort to make sure students understand the material. The methods for evaluating student understanding leaves much to be desired . Passing the course just involves memorizing things because tests are often too big and complex to solve without already knowing most of the answers.
One of the best professors i have had at SFU. Finally, for all these years I get to meet such a knowledgeable and wise prof. The lectures taught by him are great. But you really need to work for it.

his exams are hard, but the questions are fair. do practice from his homework to make sure you can speed through the easy questions, and write very detailly in your answers. lectures are a bit dull since he mostly just read his note, so do ask him if you didn't get something. the biggest flaw of his course is a quiz on the last day of class.

Kabanets covers the content well. He defines all terms that are used. The quizzes are challenging, but doable (and curved). The final has an easy bonus question (what is your favourite algorithm) that is worth something meaningful (5 bonus points out of 100 points on exam).

Course is a joke. Instructor doesn't change his tests from previous years so the course is just competitive cheating - due to this your graded very heavily on trivial mistakes and NOT on your understanding of concepts. It is easy to do well tho.

4 quizzes. Requires some critical thinking. Pauses lecture regularly and asks if we have any questions. Nice during office hours. Only thing I don't like is his voice makes me sleepy. Definitely recommended for CMPT 307.
super nice and caring . A real gem:)

The quizzes are like the assignments - with some extra things from lectures and readings. Lectures are basically where he just goes over/reads his onenote notes so the lectures tend to be quite bland. Sometimes distracted by his accent. Overall, his tests are easy to study for with what he provides you - not much extreme critical thinking imo.

We had 4 quizzes and 1 final exam. Quizzes were based on assignments which were quite challenging. Be prepared to memorize algorithms, time complexity and proof by induction so forth. You need to put decent amount of time to understand materials. Valentine teaches it well, really cares about students' learning. Overall, I recommend him
lectures are somewhat interesting and you can tell Valentine is passionate about algorithms and time complexity. Quizzes and exams are challenging

My biggest beef with him is the exams. Some of the exam questions are downright unfair, and they look nothing like the material presented during class. He likes to take some questions from obscure theoretical computing science results that only a researcher would typically be well-versed about in a THIRD YEAR COURSE.

Some of my classmates complained the assignments and midterms are brutal hard. I found them okay given that you do need to put a lot of thoughts and effort into it. Need some mathematics skills I suppose. Clear lecture, useful notes and examples.

Incredibly knowledgeable and articulate. His lectures were organized and had a good flow, leaving no gaps in understanding. They were supportive for approaching new problems in the assignments. And the assignments were designed to solidify the lecture material. An excellent teacher.

Valentine is one of the best Prof in SFU. He knows his staff and knows how to teach. The assignment is well related to quiz, and he will give the solution before the quiz. He makes this course much easier.

Very good professor! He was very clear and his pacing was good. Of all the profs I had this semester, he is the only one who marked final exams quickly and posted the marks early enough for us to ask questions. His marking was also very fair. If the TAs ever marked anything wrong, he would fix your grade. This makes all the difference in the world!
Good professor, of course. Final is not hard with bonus points. Reviewing quiz and materials will help to figure out questions. Don't expect to get a good grade without hard work.

Extremely tough subject to teach as a lot of the concepts are very tough. Almost all algorithms and little about data structures. He tries very hard to make sure you understand and encourages us to ask for help. I find the grading scheme a little tough 4 15% quizzes and a 40% final. Should be some assignments to distribute the grade more.

I didn't get a good grade in this course because I think the exams are hard, especially the last two quizes and the final exam. But the prof is a nice guy who can explain the concept and material well. His attitude is very nice and you can ask anything if you have questions.

Covered a considerable amount of the Cormen book (for a first Algorithms course). Was very enthusiastic about the material and gave a deeper insight into complexity theory than what is normal for first Algo course. Assignments were challenging but interesting and were offset by more reasonable exams.

Great professor, really interested in the subject. He goes over a lot of stuff from MACM and CMPT 225, but there is a lot of stuff to learn as well. My only complaint is that I wish we went into hashing and red black trees. His TAs were very lenient on the marking, worried I wouldn't do so well in the course but pulled out with a B!

Half the material you will have learnt from CMPT225 or other previous CS courses. The assignments are quite challenging,so you might not even be able to start,while the midterms and final are much more easier.You will have no problem if you do your assignments and understand all the assignment solutions. P.S He is also an easy marker.

Worst prof ever. He uses the chalkboard and his notes are impossible to understand. Seriously, who uses a chalkboard in this day and age for teaching. All of my other professors have either used the overhead projector or powerpoint slides. Assignments are painfully difficult. Midterms are okay if you are able to do the homework and memorize 100%.

One of the best profs in SFU CS dep. He REALLY knows what he is teaching. He is so knowledgeable in algs and complexity. He teaches clearly. So attending classes is a must. Assignments are killers and so difficult but that's the way you learn the course content. Midterms and finals are SO FARE and based on assignments.
An extremely hard subject taught clearly. Cares a lot for students. Answers questions thoroughly. Gives challenging homework but fair tests.

I was scared of this course and the lectures I went to scared me even more, as I barely ever understood everything. His assignments were also fairly challenging, but you really learn a lot from the assignments. He is a really smart prof and both midterm and final were easy in my opinion. I got an A- in this class and the average was 65% (rel. high)

I never was very good at math. However, his teaching is very good. You understand the core concepts quite well. Also, his assignments/exams and their marking are very fair, unlike many other math courses I've taken. As long as you put effort into the class, you will do OK. Everyone I've talked to likes him, and I'm not surprised.
Excellent knowledge of the subject, and very good explanations! Makes a difficult subject very easy to understand. Marking-wise, he's fair too.
Arash was very helpful, one of the most helpful professors I have ever had at SFU. He is not easy and you have to work hard, however if you make an effort, he will do his best to help you.

Arash was very helpful, one of the most helpful professors I have ever had at SFU. He is not easy and you have to work hard, however if you make an effort, he will do his best to help you. I would recommend.
funny course!
He is quite smart!
if you have any questions ,just go to his office. he is very easy with marking.
It was an OK course

Very very great professor, very patient and helpful. The only thing that sucks is the TA whose name is Haitao Li, he only knows rarely about this course and shows no respect and gives you extremely grade without comments. But thanks to the professor, he re-evaluated my exam and corrected all mistakes TA made.
without doubt a star pro in SFU
No Comments

Joseph Peters was a great prof, particularly compared to my expectation of CMPT 307. His quizzes were straightforward - they directly tested your understanding. The homework was tough but marked quite easily. His choice of textbook (CLRS) was also great. Joseph's lectures simply helped us understand the content in the book.

The content of CMPT 307 requires students to develop strong problem solving abilities over the length of the course which requires you to put in a lot of effort. Joseph Peter's lectures and homework really helped me to develop these skills and succeed in the course. He is a funny and clearly a caring person. I would certainly recommend him.

307 is a tough course and I would recommend taking it with Joseph Peters. The quiz material comes from the textbook and lectures so don't miss any classes, and he is very helpful in office hours which you will need for the assignments. The final is much harder than the quizzes.

He's probably one of the toughest prof in SFU. You may be tricked into believing that he's a lenient grader at the end of the semester, so you give him a good review. Do not believe him. He failed many students in my class because he graded his final exam brutally. If you do bad in the final, he will fail you regardless of your overall performance.
Hard to follow. He is not a good lecturer. Avoid this class.

An awesome instructor. Caring, explains concepts clearly, and is very helpful in office hours. One criticism - I feel like I got away with some BS/handwaving. The material is hard, but important to learn, so I definitely cared about understanding more than marks. Beware - the final is harder than the quizzes, and is worth 50%.

Recommended for 307; course is mostly about solving word problems rather than mostly proofs so it's an interesting course in that way. Homework and quizzes can be tough but he is very helpful and friendly in office hours.
Marks were based only on quizzes and final. Tough material so expect to study a lot.

Dr.Peters does a good job teaching a rather difficult subject.  This is perhaps the hardest CMPT course I have taken yet, yet most likely the one I have enjoyed the most so far.  He teaches in a way that encourages actual learning and thinking.  Coming up with a solution to problems is not easy, as you will find in this course.

He is one of the best professors I had. He rewards people for creative solutions to problems even if they don't work out in the end. He encourages discussion in class which unfortunately not many take advantage of. Exams require creative thinking so if you just want to memorize something, then you should rethink the reason why you are in university

I always seem to be running out of time on quizzes, and half of the course grade are based on those quizzes.  His notes are useless, so just study from the textbook.  Would not take another class with him again.

Marking is based only on many quizzes and final exam. 20 minute quizzes were given about once a week or so.  I found these quizzes hard and also he doesn't give us enough time.  Class average on these quizzes were low.  The instructor does not give out useful notes so be prepared to study from the textbook yourself.
Really difficult prof.  Would not take another course with him again.
Good professor, and very easy course, seems that almost all students get 80+

Sucks!  Can't speak or write~I can't believe the calibre of profs that sfu can only hire with the already increased tuition.  This guy can't communicate his work with students.  I saw more than 1/2 the class not hand in their hwk after midterm 1!
No Comments
He's a nice guy but he can't speak or write clearly, seriously
Excellent Class and Excellent Prof

He is the best prof that fits in what I believe to be the best way to learn and be tested. He gives clear lectures which his exams are all based on them and the homework. Even he was old school using paper and pen in class, but he is the only one prof that I have taken who uses the recording system for us to review his lectures online. Take him!!!

CMPT 307 is hard, but he makes it as simple as possible. I am surprised that his explanations for Master Formula and SELECT are way better than the ones in the textbook. The weekly assignments roughly took 15 hours each, but they are the core for getting good marks on exams. Memorizing solutions usually doesn't work, but understanding logic does.
He know his stuff.  The course is very difficult and when you ask questions, he is definitely not encouraging.  If the TA didnt help me understand some stuff, then probably would of failed.

Great proof. Killer final but very nice curve.  As long as you attend all the lecture and take notes, you should be okay. most of exam questions are from the lecture notes and homework. overall great prof.

Hard course in general, and he's well-experienced teaching it. However I wish there'd been more feedbacks for students during the semester. Seeing my grades for assignments and midterm, it was not clear to me if I'd pass the course, which embarrassed me the whole time. But at the end I'm happy with my grade.

very hard course, one of the hardest among CMPT courses.his teaching skill is above average.The assignments are very time consuming (one assignment per week).exams seem intimidating, but actually fair after u take a closer look

Very good prof, The course is taught like a math course, weekly assignments and such (some of which are hard) but thats how you learn the material. He is also crystal clear in his lectures and very approachable for help during office hours.

Very good professor, but difficult course content. He explained everything very well. The homework was not to long but it was difficult. His midterm and final exam seemed intimidating at first but they were manageable.

Good teacher, hard topic, he did well to help most of the students pass and his class always has more people passing, so i guess that means he's easier or a better teacher than other people for this class
too many assignments! one assignment per week, and each assignment takes a average student about 8 hours to finish.Do u the math.avoid him unless u don't have any other choices.
He's sometimes kind of short-tempered. Besides he's like always in a rush, seems to have more serious commitments/affiliations somewhere else.
Knows the course material very well, and teaches the stuff better than anyone at SFU.
not quite an encouraging professor
Take him should you be hardworking.

He's a famous prof and a good teacher. Although he's moody and his presentation is a bit boring. There must be a problem with his ears or his english because he didn't get some of the questions during the lectures. Very hard homework questions but he solves them right after the deadline. Too much strict for homework deadline which is the very begin

3 hours lecture. dry but understandable...  Requires alot of thinking and creativity. It always seems like hes jumping around topics and hard to follow if you are working through the textbook. 
 
 Midterm consists of 50%+ homework questions...  good for some, bad for others that don't like memorizing...

He's an awesome prof.  Heaven is a good word to describe him.  In what was always talked as the hardest CS class, he made it seem pretty understandable with simple concepts, etc.  Everyone did well in his class.  So take him!

Gives somewhat reasonable exams. He's pretty lazy as assignments and solutions often posted late and gives us only the weekend to complete them. Average teaching and the handwrote slides were hard to follow at times. He was very approachable and responsive on Piazza. On the other hand, the TAs were invisible the whole term and did nothing but mark.
our class average was c, the final exam was too difficult

David is very helpful, providing clear answers to questions outside of class and assisting with problem comprehension. The quiz and final exams are fair as long as you review the slides and problem set.The slide is a bit confusing though.

This class is graded by 5 quizzes and a final, with each quiz feeling like a midterm that takes an entire lecture. It's like having 5 midterms. Don't take this class in the morning—algorithms are dry and hard to follow. Lectures are handwritten and confusing, making it tough to decipher without watching YouTube videos to understand the material.

David is a middle-of-the-road prof. His lectures are alright, but by nature 307 requires a lot of time studying outside the lecture hall to fully understand the concepts. A few errors on sample solutions and notes, but he made corrections and responded to questions on piazza in a timely manner. He only grades by 5 quizzes + final, so study!

Yeah no, this course is too hard and with him it becomes impossible. Dont make the mistake of taking this class in the morning otherwise you'll just sacrifice your sanity to listen to this early in the morning

The course was graded by only 6 quizzes and a final exam. The content felt very dense and hard to get into. This course feels like it should be more credits. The handwritten slides adds somewhat unnecessary complexity when using them to study. Needs lots of extra time outside of lectures to properly study the content.

Had Mitchell for CMPT 225 two years ago, thought he was awful - lazy and unprepared. Took him again for CMPT 307 and he has improved tremendously, really good lectures and he provides video recordings. His quizzes are probably the most fair quizzes I've taken for any class throughout my entire degree so far. Went from Not Recommended to Recommended
Worst prof ever. Laziest and doesnt care at all. His syllabus is the laziest could be. Just take it if you wanna ruin your mental health.

Lectures were few and far between, and not always posted on time. However, his Lectures were good and he explained concepts well. If you want lots of content and a strict environment then he is not for you. He definitely made 307, which is know to be difficult, an easier experience as it felt like he cut out some of the extra material.

David is probably the laziest teacher I have ever had in my life. He doesn't even have a lecture for every class (online). However, this class wasn't too bad. He's pretty good at explaining, and the class takes minimal effort since there were no assignments. He takes forever to mark quizzes though, and the grading scheme was a bit unclear.
WORST PROF EVER!! Exams were lengthy and quite difficult. The teaching style is horrible, do yourself a favour by taking the course with someone else.
He took very long to provide grades for the midterm. Hard to track progress throughout the semester. Lazy and unresponsive.
Worst Prof ever!! Just take the course with someone else!!
Just run away and take this course with someone else. He doesn't respond to email nor does he care about students.
The best professor for teaching 307. It's a challenging course but his teaching style is best among all the professors. A GPA booster for sure if taken with David

I was worried about taking DM before the course started, but I've been pleasantly surprised. It is true that he is pretty lazy, with less than a dozen video lectures all year, but he has quality Q&A sessions and very reasonable quizzes. His lectures are informative, but do require self-study to reinforce. He's way better than his reviews here say.

Run the other direction! This class almost destroyed me. The textbook is definitely a must. Petra does not know how to teach and this course is hard enough as it is. Her assignments do NOT have solutions and cannot be easily extracted from her notes or the textbook and midterm and some of final is based off of them. Take CMPT 307 with someone else!

Lectures are brutal, her english is very difficult to understand. But her notes are actually pretty decent since they are just notes off the textbook. SUPER easy! 3 midterms, 2 of them are questions from the homework word for word (which isn't for marks or particularly difficult btw). Meaning memorize 8 hw Qs per midterm = 100%.
avoid, the worst prof i have ever had
Worst Prof among the worst. waste of time and money.
agree other peers comments abusolutely
Poor ability to communicate in English. Absolutely brutal lectures. I would never take a class from her again. Worst prof I've had here.
You better you know your stuff very well cause that's what she expects and there is no exception what so ever. She can be great help one on one but class enviroment doesn't work very well. Good luck

When you think she couldn't be any worse, she proves you wrong. absolutely horrible. She is unclear and always says "You should know this" ... and if u don't know "this" she won't bother explain ... I've had bad teachers, but she's on a whole new level of bad
Uses someone else's notes (written permission I guess) but sometimes gets lost in them. doesn't explain things too good ... lets hope I pass huh?
Even though I thought her class was difficult, I wouldn't have rated her so negatively if she hadn't been so arrogant.  She had a very poor attitude towards teaching.

The thing I like about Dr. Berenbrink is that during exams you can get away with asking any question and she will answer.  This is very helpful!  I also found her lectures extremely well-related.  Ignore all the negative comments, people are stupid.
She is great! If you like challenges, you'l love the course! Afterall she designed it only for smarties, if otherwise, you won't survive her course.
No Comments
does not know how to teach - one of the worst profs I've had
Ambiguos writing, arrogant, keep saying "You should know this and that..."
Bad handwriting, abit arrogant. The things she covered in class did not help us
No Comments
Can't speak English, can't write English, can't explain stuff, arrogant& useless
Great person, really helpful and easy to reach anytime

Ben is passionate about what he teaches. His explanations during lectures can be hard to follow, you will have to watch YouTube videos. The course closely follows slides provided by Brad Bart, another prof at SFU. Ben is very approachable for office hours and even post-lecture. Asking Ben questions will help you a lot. Poorly organized final exam.

He loves what he teaches and has a genuine passion to teach. He tries his best to ensure everyone gets the content. Will make extra effort in the office hrs to make you understand everything. He enjoys algorithms and will make you enjoy learning them too. Very caring and kind. Puts a lot of effort to make the class interesting.

This was his first time teaching his own class, and while he did have some trouble at the beginning of the year due to his inexperience, he has gotten a lot better at teaching.
He cares very much about the class and tries his best to make sure we understand the content
His assignments are also very fair, and correspond with what was taught in class

His lectures were dense and hard to follow, forcing you to learn the material on your own.  His exams were also not a great test of the material, as the averages were often failing grades. I would recommend you take this course with another professor.

MY GOAT. This prof is awesome. Although he may not be the best at lectures, he clears any professor in terms of tests. He gives clear instruction for the midterms and finals. Questions don't deviate much from what you've already done in the homework. As long as you know how to solve homework questions and don't rely on ChatGPT, you should be fine.
Terrible professor. Could not understand anything he said. Makes the concepts more harder than needed.

Very fair exams. Reasonable expectations. Hard to read questions if you're not used to mathematical notation.
Recommendation is that you don't solely rely on his slides, also look at other resources and do a few LC easy/med questions.

The problem, first of all, is that you would not understand any word he says. This is an Algorithm class, and you'd find the class challenging even with a professor who can speak clear English. Do not believe students when they say he's the GOAT. He's not! Anything you learn will be from your own self-study. It's useless attending his class.
Very lenient marking. If you don't mind learning everything on your own, you can take this to get a good mark. Lectures are just him reading the textbook.

Gu was very lenient on grading which was helpful for such a tough class. The assignments were basically free marks. The midterms and final were graded by few questions which could be tough if you didn't understand a question.

I would take 307 with him again. Sometimes he is hard to understand but he is a nice enough guy and not a bad choice.

I didn't like CMPT 307 with him at first. But as time went by, I came to enjoy it. He answered everyone's questions immediately (literally!) during lectures, and his assignments & exams were fair. The only con is that his lectures are not that good. But I think his handling of other things really makes up for it. He is also very nice and reasonable

This professor maybe not the best professor i have met in university life, but he is one of those most caring one. He always replies email very quick, not like other professors and TAs. If you have any questions, you are welcome to ask him. He is very supportive and willing to help. I never thought of passing this course with a B-.
Pretty old school (boring) lectures. Exams and assignments were graded lieniently, but that also meant there wasn't much feedback.

I agree with the good feedback below. He makes complex concepts in algorithm matters easier. I liked his way of caring for students. His exams are fair and only asked the important part of the course, not covering all the trivial details.

Professor Gu is knowledgeable in computer algorithm. His accent gave me NO TROUBLE in understanding the course, some comments here are unfair! Gu cares about his students and gave extension on the assignments/exams to students who had health issues. Everytime I asked him questions, he could answer my questions clearly and encouraged me to think.

I really like this man. He clearly knows his material. He is caring but not pretentious at all. He doesn't seem eager for praise or recognition but just does his job well. He is often amused by students' questions but answers them clearly. Students mock him because of accent and grammar but to be honest his English is really good.

The prof defines the (admittedly complex) material clearly and adequately. He is adept at understanding answering students' questions during lecture. Test difficulty is on par with assignments and feels fair. Low amount of work required (roughly 4 hour long assignments, due every 2-3 weeks). His accent may be hard to understand for some.

No effort put into classes. Lectures just zoom by advanced topics with minimal detail. His slides are only excerpts copy & pasted from the textbook. I wish he'd at least give us time to understand the material. His accent is super confusing as well. Surprised they let these kinds of professors teach!
The worst prof I've ever had at SFU. His accent is hard to understand even for Chinese speakers. He doesn't know how to teach at all, all he does is reading slides.

Accent isn't that bad once you get used to it. Slides are cryptic and he doesn't answer questions in lecture clearly. Weird terminology sometimes. He was really understanding when I had a medical issue though so thumbs up for that.
Clear and solid lectures, an ideal choice! Can heavily depend on tests but those have a fair difficulty and are fairly marked.
Really nice professor and wants to see students do well. I really enjoyed the course with him and would take it again!

Dr. Kay is one of the best prof at SFU. He is very organised and his lecture is always helping you to understand the logic not memorising. If you regularly attend the lecture and follow his advice, at least B- is there. I hope all the course could be taught by him.

Amazing professor, clear explanation and is reachable after class even when he is busy and very approachable, the only professor I enjoyed having at sfu.

For midterm and final he clearly outlined which parts of the course would come and explaining what to kind of questions to focus on making the study process very streamlined.

Amazing guy

I appreciate his kind demeanour as he is always looking to help students out to clear questions. However, he is functionally not a professor. He is extremely lazy and rips all of his course content out from the textbook line by line and its not very helpful to go to clas since hee cant explain better than the textbook. Avoid if you want to learn.
He's an amazing prof. He gives clear indication on what he expects from students and is very helpful too.
Best Prof I ever had at SFU! Teaches very well and cares about student's learning and success. Would take again. 10/10
Good professor, humurous, and understands students do not have the luxury to invest all their time into one Math course. Tells you what to expect on the exams. 10/10 would take again
Nice guy but course itself is horrible. Final is 50% linear programming, do prepare for that.

While lecture can be boring, he's a passionate professor and would answer and engage with any students who have questions. If you do your assignments, and review all concepts carefully (keyword - all), you would do well. Grades are fair, and for our class we get 66% average for midterm, which is pretty good in my opinion.

Avoid taking CMPT307 taught by Dr. Wiese if you want to learn computing algorithms. His lecture is very boring. He spends 70% of lecture time repeating the content from the textbook word by word. What makes it worse is the textbook he picked is not good (very ambiguous when discussing in-depth algorithms). He is a nice and polite prof. though.

Not sure why he pre-recorded everything. If there's no incentive to be in class, then students will cram instead of watching when they should. I couldn't bring myself to watch them all because he talks so slow and boring. Makes exam questions out of 10-20 marks but gives either full marks or a zero. Although I got an A- I self-studied a lot.
some assignments have online solutions, and people get around 38/40 average for these assignments. final is fair

Worst prof. Do you really want to pay hella expansive tuition fee just to hear a dude reads off his terrible slides word by word with absolutely no extra explanation nor context then gives unreasonable hard assignments????? SFU don't increase the tuition fee when you are just gonna hire someone to just read off the slides.

He exhibits zero passion when teaching. If you ACTUALLY have a passion for learning DON'T take his class -.- his super boring lectures provide zero value to your understanding and you have to watch them at 2x speed cause he talks so s l o w l y ! ! ! Skip taking class with him, he is a waste of your parents money lol.

The course itself is pretty hard. His lecture was not the best, but it was acceptable, given the materials were extremely hard. Couple professors from YouTube were more clear. 1/3 of people still failed the midterm after he changed the total mark from 35 to 32. Surprisingly almost no one failed the final, guess he either bumped up everyone grades.

He's a very neutral professor - fairly decent at teaching, provides fair assignments and exams and does what he needs to do to run the class. To put it lightly, he's a bit of an ass sometimes but it seems like that's just his personality. Tough grader, doesn't sugarcoat anything. Take this class with him if you are already strong in the subject.

Brad Bart honest review:
- Very good lecturer
- Extremely hard and time consuming assignments (with poor sample solutions)
- Exams felt fair, but averages were extremely low (my grade included)
- Kind of a dick (sometimes he's nice)

Only take this prof if you want to learn and not just pass, he will fail you if he can.

Brad Bart is a good lecturer and all the lectures are recorded. However, only a lot of leetcode saved me in some of the assignments which were many and difficult. You end up learning a lot about algorithms and dynamic programming, but the grading is very strict and the exam and overall grade average was low.

RUNN....
Avoid at all costs! If you want a terrible experience, enroll in his class. He hovers around, pressuring students to answer his confusing questions, which he struggles to grasp himself. He endlessly repeats the same material and lacks knowledge beyond that.
Take other section if possible (B.B failed 1/3+ of the class with a C avg).

Weekly hw, two mts, and a final. DO NOT fall behind. You WILL learn a lot if u treat this course like a FT job. Final was VERY tricky w/ little part marks. He will adjust the 50% pass final rule slightly. Final exam avg was failing & grade avg was a C. 1/3 of class failed. Pray daily. I lost at least 10 years off my life span from this course.

Rude and self righteous. A lot of students got a question wrong on a midterm. Instead of pointing them in the right direction he said he would fail everyone who got it wrong if he could. "That's disappointing", "you screwed it up" if you try to answer his questions during lecture. That's just the tip of the iceberg. Oh and 1/3 of the class failed.
RUN

Excellent lecturer, simply explains the big ideas and intuition behind concepts and helps you build your own intuition around a concept and actually learn instead of just reading off the slides. I still remember a lot of the concepts since he helps you build your intuition instead of getting you to memorize. Highly recommended.
There is a lot of homework, the exam is very difficult. It directly hit my interest in learning computer programing.
Challenging assignments and exams but the lectures were really well put together. Would recommend taking courses with Brad if you really want to learn.

Brad is a very very average teacher. However, if you are not a genius, but you have the top genius people's strange temper. Then you are worse than an average one.

if you guys don't know what I am saying, try to go to his office hours to feel it.

An incredibly difficult but fun class. Almost felt like the Dark Souls CMPT course of SFU, to be honest. With the way he's teaching currently, it's easy to tell that he cares about his teaching and his students. His assignments challenge you and his reflective exercises are an opportunity for you to give him feedback.

He doesn't provide notes but he is a great lecturer. You get assignments pretty much every week but they are usually not very long and are good to test your knowledge. Quizzes are generally pretty easy if you know your materials well.
I really liked his way of teaching, as well as his notes. Homework's a bit hard though.

I took his 295 class years ago and was honestly dreading this course given the experience back then. But his class and lectures were actually very nice and clearly prepared with care!! He really cares about the material and our learning. He seems easy-going and I can proudly say I attend lectures without shaking in my boots this time around!

Is it tough? Yeah, but you might actually learn something. Brad seems like he actually cares about what he is teaching which is more than I can say for most of the profs I've had at sfu. Weekly assignments and multiple quizzes is a lot but it helps keep you on top the course material and spreads out the marks which is nice. Also took 295 with him.

Makes you write a lot of notes. It's impossible to pay attention to what he's teaching, writing notes takes up the whole class. Doesn't post filled notes either. Otherwise, he seems like a decent teacher.

He is good at giving lectures and really knows his stuff. So I don't know why he needs to rule over the class with an iron fist. I don't know if he believes instilling fear is the only way to maintain order or if he's trying to 'assert dominance' over his students with frivolous rules that he will enforce at all costs. It's quite a shame.
Worst instructor ever!!!

Brad seems like a fun individual at first, but he doesn't know how to properly approach a student who is struggling with the subject. He's intimidating and doesn't make you feel the brightest during his office hours. Definitely doesn't know how to give his students the best support they can get. Doesn't seem very encouraging . Don't take his class

One of the best professors ever. He can explain things very well. I think his lectures are more understandable than the text book. The average grade of this course may not high, but this is definitely not the problem of the professor but the course itself. Algorithms may be the most  difficult  but important subject of computing science.
9 assignments 3 quizzes, dont take this prof if you are not taking his course full time
If you decide to read the textbook and do those assignments carefully, you will learn a lot. Be prepared for 9 assignments and 3 quiz in the semester with him.
Not so hard, don't get freaked out easily. Lot of concepts and examples, just review after classes and go through the textbook, I think that'll help.
Very tough course with a tough  prof.  However, I  did learn a lot .
BB is really a good guy. He can memorize almost everyone's name is his class. Really helpful. The course is hard though, actually harder than other CMPT307. But his course is worth taking
We were lucky that this semester brad had taught this course. Really enjoyed the course and learned a lot, I am glad that I took the course him
I would say avoid courses by Brad Bart.
Can't deliver the material
Stay the phack away, most dreaded professor ever, better start his assignments ATLEAST a week before they are due. And he WILL NOT respond to emails.
This guy is awesome, but you have to attend his class or you'll be screwed.  The assignments are hard, but the topics are interesting, and he's a very good lecturer.

Class was everything I wanted.  Detailed explanations of algorithms, formal proofs.  I didn't pay $500 to sit back and receive 3 credits like some of these other posters seem to have wanted.  This teacher is very good, and if you put in the effort you will do well.

His assignment really test your thinking of the problems. Not big on proofs on mid-terms and final exams. His lectures show his great understanding of the topic and contain alot of examples. His lectures are not boring, but you need to pay attention.
Hard but mostly fair.  Attend all lectures, assignments are heavily based on examples in class.

Awful. The worst prof i had at sfu. Not interested in teaching, no notes, writes on blackboard, horrible explanations, no clear solutions for exams and assignment. Run from him at all costs. Course is kinda hard on top of things.
Midterm was on the hard side, but he explains the material well.  He's really sharp and enjoys going beyond the required material.  Recommended for those who enjoy learning.
Comes in, flips open the book and starts copying on the board.  NO interest whatsoever in teaching.  Avoid at all costs.
Boring and can't understand him.  Exams are difficult.
Awful teaching style. The only good point is the easy marking in exams...

Very unenthused.  He could not explain any concepts, not even basic algorithms to the class.  I left his class more confused about algorithms than before I took the class.  Definitely an awful professor who should focus on publications more than teaching.

One of my worse professors ever at SFU.
 Lack of clarity. Difficulty: insane
avoid at all cost..can't teach at all..says everything's  stupid ..
he was my nightmare
No Comments
No Comments
very disorganized, worst prof i've ever had
No Comments
disorganized, doesn't devote enough time

Art is a good teacher and is always available for extra help (which you WILL need). HOWEVER, he gives VERY difficult exams and is also a very strict marker. The midterm average was 20-30%, and I'm pretty sure more than half the class failed. Though I like Art, I advise you wait for a different prof unless you thought MACM 201 was an easy course.

He teaches the material well, exams are fair. Unfortunately, he seemed to have an irrational hatred for our class. Midterms were arbitrarily remarked and marked down A LOT. He then flipped out on us and said he wouldnèt scale. Final was really easy, yet his marking, again... put the average way below 50%. More than half the class failed.
Had a very negative attitude and marked the class brutally. 40 students, and the third highest mark was a C+. One of the most negative experiences I've had at SFU.
The worst teacher ever. I don't know how this guy is still allowed to teach. Avoid him at all cost.

Great at teaching a difficult subject.  Any problems usually came from the complexity of the subject, no from him.  Able to keep things light and entertaining even when you brain is about to explode.  Pop-quizes were great in forcing you to keep up with the material.  Tests/assignments were hard but fair.
Engaging prof, wry but lively sense of humour (as long as you don't ask stupid questions, you should be fine...).  Midterms and quizzes were hard but fair.

One word. HARD!!!!!! Exclamation point. The class average is around 30%. NO online notes (just handwritten) brutal pop quizzes, brutal midterm, convers tons of material. However if you keep up and read the text (yeah right) you can do ok, but kiss your GPA good bye.
6 'HARD' surprise quizes worth 20%!!  The midterm was hard, he talks while he writes, and has very messy handwritting to boot!  Some say he's funny, some say he's cocky...
Funny as far as CS profs go, which is to say, not very funny at all. Good teaching style.
He is not good prof
Just the right amount of work and complexity. Fair.
Tough and tricky if you haven't paid your dues yet.
